title: Are knights nobility or gentry? - Quora

response.answer_text: At first they were lower gentry, and in late medeival times they had to be born noble and were called milites nobiles, and then knighthood was more limited to the nobles only. From the 15th to 18th centuries the Lords helped appointing Knights of the 50 shires from the gentry to influence and lead the commons in parliament. The Royal house has appointed around 250 European Royal honorary knights in the last 600 years. And the Order of the Garter from 1350 is a noble knighthood only for the sovereign, the Prince of Wales and maximum 24 living persons. In Sweden there is a House of Nobility since 400 years called the House of Knights, which was the seat of the Nobles in the Parliament of the Four States, until abolished via reforms in representation in 1865.

Depends on the country. Knights are nobility (lower nobility) in Belgium and the Netherlands. In the UK, they are not considered nobility with respect to House of Lords. Other countries vary. Some do not have formal aristocracies anymore, but the knights would have been included at the time when the aristocracies fell (still got beheaded in the French Revolution).

In the medieval era, knighthood was the lowest of the ranks of nobility. The title could only be conferred on his eldest son, and had to be maintained every generation in that way or they lost their rank. Lapsed lower nobility and cadet bloodlines of noble families are where the “gentry” come from, referred to extensively in the period as gentleman or women, as having “gentle blood”.
Gentry In the UK Knights and Baronets do not get a seat in the House of Lords, and can sit in the House of Commons Nobility starts with Barons.

In the UK, the noble ranks are: Duke, Marquess, Earl, Viscount, and Baron (plus female equivalents). Below this, and aristocratic but not noble, are: Baronet and Knight. Both of these are entitled to be called ‘Sir’, but only the Baronetcy is inheritable (or was… that may have changed).
